awd_titl_txt: Collaborative research: How variable is magma decompression rate during a single eruption?
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding the processes that govern transitions in volcanic eruptive style is one of the major outstanding questions in volcanology, with important implications for hazard mitigation efforts. Syneruptive magma decompression rate is thought to be a dominant control on volcanic eruptive style, due in part to its role in modulating the dynamics of bubble formation and migration. In recent years, techniques have been developed that use chemical gradients in rapidly quenched volcanic tephra to constrain magma decompression rates; however, the rarity of suitable samples for the application of these techniques has severely limited the acquisition of statistically robust datasets that could be used to explore temporal variations in magma decompression rate over the course of a single eruption. A newly developed magma decompression “clock” that exploits water concentration gradients in prevalent olivine crystals can now be used to overcome this limitation. We propose to apply this new magma decompression clock to study temporal variations in the decompression rate of magma erupted at Cinder Cone, Lassen Volcanic National Park, CA. The exceptionally well-preserved tephra sequence from Cinder Cone captures a transition in eruptive style from Hawaiian/Strombolian to Strombolian/Violent Strombolian, providing an excellent natural laboratory for studying the role of decompression rate as a control on eruptive style. The Lassen region is one of the most active volcanic regions in the US and poses a significant hazard to Californians, National Park visitors, and flights to and from the busy San Francisco Bay Area. The results of the proposed work will be shared with the California Volcano Observatory, the Cascade Volcano Observatory, and Lassen Volcanic National Park, which manage volcano-monitoring infrastructure and volcanic hazard mitigation efforts in California.

In the proposed work, variations in magma decompression rate will be studied in the context of syneruptive temperature changes and textural variations in the 1666 C.E. Cinder Cone eruptive deposit. We will apply three independent techniques to estimate magma decompression rates: (1) water-in-olivine diffusion chronometry; (2) bubble number density; and (3) microlite number density. Additionally, we will constrain magma cooling rates using MgO zonation in olivine-hosted melt inclusions. We will build a statistically robust dataset of decompression rate and cooling rate estimates that will be used to assess (for the first time in a basaltic system) temporally resolved variations in decompression rate and cooling rate across a transition in eruptive style. This approach will allow the evolution of pressure-temperature- time conditions in the conduit just prior to eruption to be studied in unprecedented detail, thereby increasing our understanding of the controls on the explosivity of basaltic volcanic eruptions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project outcomes report highlights contributions made by PI Walowski and students at Western Washington University (WWU), in collaboration with Dr. Megan Newcombe at the University of Maryland (UMD). The work focused on eruption processes and hazards of cinder cone volcanoes. Despite the abundance of cinder cone volcanoes in the Cascade Range and their likelihood to pose volcanic hazards in the northwestern United States, these types of volcanoes are vastly understudied, especially when compared to more evolved and longer-lived stratovolcanoes, like Mount St. Helens and Mount Rainier. This NSF funded project allowed us to explore the connections between magma ascent rate and explosivity of these mafic arc cinder cone magmas through a case study of the 1666 eruption of Cinder Cone, northern California, which is the youngest cinder cone volcano in the contiguous US.

The results of the project have improved our understanding of conduit dynamics during explosive eruptions of mafic magmas. The eruption of Cinder Cone had two main phases: a Hawaiian to Strombolian Style phase (low to moderate explosivity), and a Strombolian to violent Strombolian phase (moderate to high explosivity). In our initial proposal, we hypothesized that the more explosive eruption phase was driven by more rapid decompression rates. We used multiple quantitative methods to estimate decompression rates, including microlite number density, bubble number density, and H+ diffusion in olivine. The combined results found that the more explosive phase tended to have slower decompression rates, in contrast to our initial hypothesis. Thus, our data supports an alternate hypothesis that the eruptive style transition was driven by degassing induced crystallization and plug formation in the conduit. That is, Strombolian to violent Strombolian paroxysms (more explosive) are pulsatory in nature and represent a cyclic process of producing and destroying a crystal-rich plug near the top of the conduit. This process would result in slower average, but more variable, decompression rates relative to the lower explosivity Hawaiian-style, which is driven by a persistent high flux of magma. Continued work aims to help constrain what drove the increase in degassing induced crystallization that shifted the eruption style and help understand dynamic variation between Strombolian and violent Strombolian eruption styles, which are both observed at Cinder Cone.

Over the funding period, the project supported six undergraduate research students at WWU. Of those students, three are now in geoscience graduate programs (MS and PhD levels), and one is currently applying to graduate programs in geoscience. Not only did students learn research skills that made them more competitive candidates, but the experience helped foster a sense of belonging in the field and confidence in their ability to pursue it further. Mentorship and collaboration with research university scientists (at the University of Maryland) and Cascade Volcano Observatory scientists also played an important role in supporting these students through the research and graduate application processes. 

 


Last Modified: 04/10/2025
Modified by: Kristina Janine Walowski
